title: Dad cancels holiday over fears family will be trapped after Brexit
text:

A dad has cancelled his Christmas holiday over fears his family will be separated at the border after Brexit.

David Kís, 41, from Czech Republic, says he has experienced an increased amount of hostility at work since the EU referendum.

And he says his family will not be going home this Christmas because he fears his family will not be allowed back in.

Mr Kís moved to the UK 18 years ago with the hope of building a better life for his daughter away from discrimination.

"I'm Eastern European, I just wanted a life for my daughter, in my country if they see you have got a little bit darker skin you have to deal with racists," he said.

Mr Kís has been a bouncer for 25 years, mostly working two jobs to provide for his family, and has worked the Derby nightlife scene for many of those years.

He has claimed that since the Brexit situation began, he has experienced an increased amount of hostility from party-goers.

"I never had that many issues but especially after Brexit I'm constantly hearing remarks and I don't want to pull the race card every time I'm throwing people out.

"But, they get aggressive towards me because I'm a non-English bouncer," he said.

(Image: Peter Summers)

The dad-of-one said he has been granted full settled status after he applied two months ago, but his wife and daughter are yet to hear their decisions.

Despite spending £1,200 on flights back home to the Most district of the Czech Republic for Christmas this year, Mr Kís said the family will not be going anywhere.

He said: "I've booked Christmas flights home, it cost me £1,200 but I can't go because I'm not going to risk it.

"It's been more than two months since my wife and daughter applied for settled status and they haven't got a decision."

(Image: Peter Summers)

European nationals who have been living in the UK for more than five years have the opportunity to apply for settled status.

If granted, this means they are able to freely live and work in the UK past the date of December 2020, or when Britain leaves the EU.

Currently, the government is offering two types of settled status, including pre-settled status which is given to people who do not have five years continuous residence when they apply.

(Image: Dan Kitwood)

Mr Kís, who lives in Alvaston, said he is concerned because pre-settled status does not offer the same stability and applicants are obliged to reapply for settled status later on.

As well as that, Mr Kís said it is stressful for the family because his wife does not work and has little to prove she has been in the UK for five years.

"Because I work all the time, I have two jobs, my wife is a stay-at-home mum. All the bills are under my name, how can she prove that she's been here for five years," he said.

He said his wife and daughter "feel that they want to go back" because there is "too much pressure."

(Image: Dan Kitwood)

Now 17-years-old, his daughter has lived her whole life in the UK and is currently studying at a college in Derby.

Part of the reason he is reluctant to go anywhere is because if on returning to the UK, the family are split at border control, it would "ruin her education."

"She's been in English schools since she was five years old and they still want me to prove it that she's been here for more than five years.

(Image: Dan Kitwood)

"It's funny, well it's not funny, but the way they've asked me to prove it, it's got to be funny," he added.

The Derby doorman said he is "annoyed" about Brexit and "angry" with the people who voted for it.

He added: "Whatever they voted for, even if they voted to leave the EU, fine, but leave people living here alone."
description: The Czech native says he has been experiencing hostility at work since the EU referendum
